Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Carbon-Ceramic Composite Membranes for Olefin-Paraffin Separations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project seeks to establish the feasibility of carbon-ceramic membranes for the highly difficult molecular separation of olefin/paraffin mixtures. Carbon molecular sieves are porous materials that possess small selective pores distributed in two to three relatively narrow size ranges that can provide the resulting membranes with high selectivity for olefin/paraffin analog separations. This project will develop a novel process to make new rigid carbon-ceramic structures that are chemically and thermally stable, and thereby, resistant to plasticization induced by absorption of hydrocarbons. This project is expected to lead to the development of carbon membranes with sufficient olefin permeance and olefin/paraffin selectivity to yield an efficient process to recover olefins that are currently flared in polyolefin plant vent gases. Moreover, this research is expected to increase the understanding of carbon-ceramic membranes and their potential for use in an array of chemically and thermally challenging gas separations that are not possible with conventional polymeric membranes.

The broader/commercial impact of this project will be the large economic potential associated with the successful commercial use of the new carbon membranes in molecular separations, considering the commercial value of the recovered olefins, and the large volumes of olefins and polyolefins consumed annually in the United States. If these inherently stable new carbon membranes are successfully developed, they could be used as an energy-efficient separation method in variety of large industrial applications including olefin/paraffin separations for monomer production at steam crackers and recovery of olefins from fluid catalytic cracker off-gases in refineries. With the appropriate membrane materials, membrane-based separations offer the advantage of substantially reduced energy consumption compared to other separation methods including absorption and distillation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project was to develop novel plasticization-resistant carbon-ceramic composite membranes for olefin/paraffin separations. Systems based on such membranes could provide serious competition to distillation, the workhorse separation technology of the petrochemical and refining industries.  Development of effective membranes has the potential to cut the cost of olefin/paraffin separations in half, reducing the cost of ethylene and propylene production by two to six cents per pound.

 

During Phase I, we screened a number of polymer precursors and pyrolysis conditions. The best of these membranes showed mixed-gas propylene/propane selectivities combined with stable propylene permeances suitable for use at industrially relevant conditions.  The membranes show strong resistance to plasticization, which is a significant advantage over polymeric-based membranes for this application. Process design studies suggest that the membrane performance achieved in the Phase I work makes membrane separation highly attractive for propylene recovery from purge streams. 

 

Considering the relatively thick carbon layer of the current composite membranes, there is a great potential to further improve the membrane flux by reducing the thickness of the carbon layer.  With NSF approval, it is our intent to submit an SBIR Phase II proposal for further development of the membranes identified in Phase I for use in olefin/paraffin applications. In addition, field demonstration of our membranes using a flare gas slipstream from a polypropylene plant will be conducted during Phase II. 


Last Modified: 01/14/2011
Modified by: Xiaotong Wei

Systems based on such membranes could provide serious competition to distillation, the workhorse separation technology of the petrochemical and refining industries. Development of effective membranes has the potential to cut the cost of olefin/paraffin separations in half, reducing the cost of ethylene and propylene production by two to six cents per pound. During Phase I, we screened a number of polymer precursors and pyrolysis conditions. The best of these membranes showed mixed-gas propylene/propane selectivities combined with stable propylene permeances suitable for use at industrially relevant conditions. The membranes show strong resistance to plasticization, which is a significant advantage over polymeric-based membranes for this application. Process design studies suggest that the membrane performance achieved in the Phase I work makes membrane separation highly attractive for propylene recovery from purge streams. Considering the relatively thick carbon layer of the current composite membranes, there is a great potential to further improve the membrane flux by reducing the thickness of the carbon layer. With NSF approval, it is our intent to submit an SBIR Phase II proposal for further development of the membranes identified in Phase I for use in olefin/paraffin applications.
